statement:
Let $A$ be a nonnegative matrix. Denote its spectrum by $\sigma(A)$.
Then the spectral radius $\rho(A)$ is an eigenvalue, that is,
$\rho(A)\in \sigma(A)$, and is associated to a nonnegative eigenvector.

If, in addition, $A$ is an irreducible matrix, then
$|\rho(A)|\geq |\lambda|$, for all $\lambda\in \sigma(A)$,
$\lambda\neq \rho(A)$, and $\rho(A)$ is a simple eigenvalue associated
to a positive eigenvector.

If, in addition, $A$ is a primitive matrix, then $\rho(A)>|\lambda|$ for
all $\lambda\in\sigma(A)$, $\lambda\neq\rho(A)$.
